etymologies: mid 16th century; earliest use found in Edmund Bonner (?1500–1569), bishop of London. In some forms from bride + man

definitions: Originally: a man who is chosen to act as an attendant of the bridegroom at a wedding, and who performs various ceremonial duties for him; a groomsman. Now usually: a male attendant of a bride.

notes.text: Often a young unmarried man, and sometimes (especially in early use) one of a number of such men at a given wedding. Compare bride-leader, "best man".
